I guess we are discussing integrity of data here :).  Either way, Yahoo is usually good with dividends (at least when I try to look those up).  I don't see dividend as the reason, especially because market usually subtracts the price of the dividend on the ex date.  You may try to figure whom Yahoo uses (Esignal, INet etc etc) and if they recently switched.  Each island may report the last price that went through on that island and if Yahoo is accessing that data, it could attribute for the change in your input data.

Aleks

John Peberdy <john@...> wrote:                                  Hi Aleks,
Well the strange thing is that I got the data from yahoo in the first place also. Maybe yahoo changed the way they calculate the adj closes sometime between feb and now. I guess another possibility is maybe yahoo doesn't recieve dividend information for a couple of weeks/months after they're issued so when I downloaded that data it wasn't entirely up to date? 



John
 


On 9/12/06, Aleks <siliconcube@...> wrote:                                    Could it be that the prices you downloaded were as of 4:00pm but Yahoo adjusted to AH closing prices?

Aleks



John Peberdy < john@...> wrote:
                             
Sort of off topic here but has anyone noticed that  finance.yahoo.com
 has changed the adjusted closes of some companies around February
 2006. I first downloaded a bunch of data around that time and inserted
 it into a database. Recently I've written a script to update my 
 database and at least one of the adjusted closes for about 50% of the
 companies are off, but  all the other data is fine!
 
 I'm currently working on a script to to check the
 database-finance.yahoo consistency further but I'll get back to you if
 I notice any order to the changing data
 
 John 
 








 
     
                       


  Rival
  
  If crime doesn't pay, does that mean my job is a crime?
